awd_titl_txt: The Interplay between Combinatorics, Set Theory, and Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to use the results, methods, and techniques that originate in combinatorics to address problems in logic, ergodic theory, and topological dynamics. Combinatorics is the area of mathematics concerning discrete structures, such as graphs, which can be viewed as mathematical objects representing networks consisting of nodes with links between them. This area has experienced immense growth in the past several decades, owing in part to its close connection to computer science. Recently, it has become apparent that combinatorial insights can shed new light on problems in other, seemingly unrelated, areas, such as ergodic theory - the study of the evolution of dynamical systems, encompassing a range of applications from epidemic models to planetary motion. It turns out that one can often associate a graph or another discrete structure to a dynamical system and then use combinatorial methods to elucidate its properties. The goals of this project are to extend the range of applications of this approach and develop new powerful combinatorial tools for the needs of other areas. The PI will work with graduate and undergraduate students through problem solving workshops and other collaborations. 

More specifically, this project revolves around transferring ideas from graph coloring theory and probabilistic combinatorics to the setting where it is necessary to fulfill additional regularity constraints (measure-theoretic, topological, etc.). Particular avenues of investigation that will be covered in this project include: (a) studying the extent to which classical probabilistic tools, especially the Lovász Local Lemma, can be extended to the measurable framework; (b) finding new methods for building measurable colorings, matchings, and other useful structures in graphs; (c) applying combinatorial techniques to attack major open problems in dynamical systems, such as the entropy problem and the Ellis problem; and (d) studying the interplay between descriptive set theory and computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project is the use of results, methods, and techniques that originate in combinatorics to address problems in other areas, such as logic, ergodic theory, and topological dynamics. Combinatorics is the area of mathematics concerning discrete structures. A typical example of such a structure is a graph, which is a mathematical model of a network consisting of nodes with links between them. Combinatorics has experienced immense growth in the past several decades, owing in part to its close connection to computer science. Recently, it has become apparent that combinatorial insight can shed new light on problems in other, seemingly unrelated, areas, such as ergodic theory - the study of the evolution of dynamical systems, encompassing a range of applications from epidemic models to planetary motion. It turns out that one can often associate a graph or another discrete structure to a dynamical system and then use combinatorial methods to elucidate its properties. This project developed new combinatorial tools for the needs of other areas and sharpened the existing ones.

Most of the research supported by this award belonged to the field called descriptive combinatorics, which studies constructive solutions to combinatorial problems on structures arising in other areas of mathematics. A key takeaway from this project is that it is worthwhile to seek general, multi-purpose approaches to descriptive combinatorics rather than treating specific problems on a case-by-case basis. In particular, the project resulted in the development of novel flexible probabilistic tools that can be used in descriptive combinatorics, and in the creation of a general mechanism by which facts from theoretical computer science can be transferred to the descriptive combinatorics setting. These results, as well as their numerous applications in descriptive combinatorics, dynamical systems, and beyond, were presented in several publications supported by this award.

In addition to supporting research efforts, this project's funding was used to cover travel costs to attend conferences and workshops in which the PI presented the project's results, thereby disseminating knowledge to diverse communities of scientists.

Furthermore, the project's funding was instrumental in helping the PI train undergraduate researchers and graduate students, contributing the the effort of raising a new generation of experts in combinatorics and its applications to other fields. In particular, the PI has been successfully introducing descriptive combinatorics to junior researchers with discrete mathematics and computer science backgrounds and no prior training in set theory, logic, dynamical systems, or other fields where descriptive combinatorics is applied. This work has strengthened the ties binding different areas of mathematics together and facilitated an increased exchange of ideas among the project's core areas.
